column1: Table 6.5A. Full-Time Equivalent Employees by Industry
Table 6.5A. Full-Time Equivalent Employees by Industry

column2: Bituminous and other soft coal mining2
Iron and steel and their products, including ordnance
Miscellaneous manufacturing, including instruments and miscellaneous plastic products4
Local utilities and public services, n.e.c.
Security and commodity brokers, and services
Credit agencies (other than banks) and holding and other investment companies
Commercial and trade schools and employment agencies5

column1: 1. Full-time equivalent employees equals the number of employees on full-time schedules plus the number of employees on part-time schedules converted to a full-time basis. The number of full-time equivalent employees in each industry is the product of the total number of employees and the ratio of average weekly hours per employee for all employees to the average weekly hours per employee on full-time schedules.
3. For 1948, included in lumber and basic timber products (line 16).
4. For 1948, included with iron and steel and their products, including ordnance (line 19).
5. For 1948, included with educational services, n.e.c. (line 71).
Note. Estimates in this table are based on the 1942 Standard Industrial Classification (SIC).
